page.title: 10The Medieval Mill
page.content: When William the Conqueror ordered the great Doomsday Survey of England in 1086 there was a mill on the site of the present hotel called the Frogmill. The mill was valued at 10 shillings at the time of the Conqueror. In Medieval England a peasant was not allowed to grind his own corn but had to bring his corn to the manorial mill to be ground by the miller, who was a servant of the Lord of the Manor. In early Medieval days the miller took one twentieth part of the corn he ground for the Lord of the Manor and this formed a valuable part of the income of the Manor and so the life of the village depended on the mill.
